A **wight**, W, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM") and [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"). The wight is a stronger type of [wraith](/wiki/Wraith_\(monster_class\) "Wraith (monster class)") that will seek out and collect items.

A wight has two [life draining](/wiki/Life_drain "Life drain") claw attacks, with a bite attack in between. Wights possess [cold resistance](/wiki/Cold_resistance "Cold resistance"), [sleep resistance](/wiki/Sleep_resistance "Sleep resistance"), [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance"), and [drain resistance](/wiki/Drain_resistance "Drain resistance").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)
- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)
- [3 History](#History)
- [4 Origin](#Origin)
- [5 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)
- [6 References](#References)

## Generation

Randomly generated wights are always created hostile.

A wight has a 1⁄2 chance of [being generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") a random type of [robe](/wiki/Robe_\(SLASH%27EM\) "Robe (SLASH'EM)").[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

A wight that leaves behind a [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") on death will always leave an [old](/wiki/Old "Old") corpse.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

## Strategy

Wights can be deadly if you lack high [magic cancellation](/wiki/Magic_cancellation_\(3.4.3\) "Magic cancellation (3.4.3)"), and are one of the many monsters that exemplify the increased need for a drain resistance source. Luckily, there are plentiful [cloak](/wiki/Cloak "Cloak") sources of MC3, which will render their drain attacks all but harmless.

Unlike the corpses of actual [wraiths](/wiki/Wraith "Wraith"), wight corpses are useless to players: they are generated too old for [sacrifice](/wiki/Sacrifice "Sacrifice"), will likely inflict [food poisoning](/wiki/Food_poisoning "Food poisoning") and do not grant any nutrition, [experience levels](/wiki/Experience_level "Experience level") or intrinsics, though a [Necromancer](/wiki/Necromancer "Necromancer")'s pet [ghoul](/wiki/Ghoul "Ghoul") will happily dig into them.

## History

The wight is one of many new monsters introduced in [SLASH 6](/wiki/SLASH_6 "SLASH 6"), an ancestor variant of SLASH'EM.

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Wight](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wight "wikipedia:Wight")***

A wight (Old English *wiht*) is a mythical sentient being, often undead. The Old English word originally described a living human being, and has since come to be used within fantasy works such as *A Song of Ice and Fire* and *Vampire: The Masquerade* to describe immortal ghost-like beings. The earliest example of the modern wight is in [William Morris's](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Morris "wikipedia:William Morris") 1869 translation of the *[Grettis saga](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grettis_saga "wikipedia:Grettis saga")*, a work of Icelandic family prose; here, *haugbui* (referring to undead monsters Glámr and Kárr) is translated as "barrow-wight".

*NetHack* most likely derives wights from their 1974 inclusion in *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")*, where they are light-hating evil spirits that can only be damaged by silver and magical weapons. Wights can drain life energy levels with their single attack, reducing the target's experience level by one; humans fully drained by wights become half-strength wights themselves under their killer's control. Wight are immune to charming, holding/paralyzing spells, poison, and sleep- or cold-based spells - holy water can damage a wight, and the "raise dead" spell can outright destroy them.

## Encyclopedia entry

When he came to himself again, for a moment he could recall nothing except a sense of dread. Then suddenly he knew that he was imprisoned, caught hopelessly; he was in a barrow. A Barrow-wight had taken him, and he was probably already under the dreadful spells of the Barrow-wights about which whispered tales spoke. He dared not move, but lay as he found himself: flat on his back upon a cold stone with his hands on his breast.

\[ The Fellowship of the Ring, by J.R.R. Tolkien ]
